But I think it’s the best thing I can do for my people.Look how China offers economic incentives to encourage its citizens to go to the West to study – and then to return and work for the improvement of their country and their people. The Chinese government recognises the importance of building an educated corps of citizens.I was thinking of this the other day on the bus, as the conductor shouted at me and the other passengers to squeeze up and make way for a fresh wave of commuters climbing aboard. You know how it is in Yangon during rush hour. Maybe it’s like that in China too, even for people with a Western education.When you have to face problems like getting on and off a crowded bus every day, it’s easy to think my friends are right. But when I think of the wealth and power of the United States, and of China, and the way China is developing its future, I start to see that I’m doing the right thing in putting my investment to work in my own country. It will be a slow process, and my friends might not be convinced. But maybe one day they will see.

Title: Real estate sector hopes for introduction of home loans
News_content: The recent opening of new private banks has spurred speculation that home buyers will eventually be able to take out a mortgage, a common practice in countries with a more highly developed financial sector.          But nobody is expecting this to happen any time soon, real estate sources said.“The government offers companies loans for industrial investment and expansion, but no loans are available for cars or homes. If a mortgage system were introduced, we would have to review our regulations,” said U Pe Myint, managing director of the Cooperative Bank.The possibility has arisen because the financial sector in Myanmar is controlled by the Central Bank, and the new government to emerge from next month’s election could therefore affect policy.One factor that could influence the authorities is the continuing fallout from the global financial crisis of 2008. Though Myanmar, having no significant financial sector, escaped the immediate effects, it has suffered like most other countries from the subsequent recession.“In China, there are many buildings for sale, but no buyers. Since these buildings were funded by bank loans, the developers have to surrender them to the banks when they cannot repay the loans. The bankruptcies in the United States occurred for similar reasons. We have to take this into account before making a decision,” said U Pe Myint.Real estate agents see a boost for their business if banks are able to give long-term home loans, which would stimulate spending.“Banks should give long-term loans. It could help the real estate sector a lot,” said one agent from Mingalar Taung Nyunt township.“Agencies suffered from the bank collapse in Myanmar in 2003 because loans were handed out without any conditions or controls,” he added. But proper financial policy and management could generate funds for construction and new business, he predicted.“Chinese banks are continuing to lend despite the financial crisis in the US and Europe. Banks should lend money for housing as well as industrial development. Then demand will increase and the property sector will develop,” he said.Strong financial flows and increasing demand for homes could also strengthen the middle class, he said.“More homes will be built and sold on contract, and the number of unsold homes or abandoned construction sites will fall,” said an agent in Kyauktada township.“A mortgage system is the key way of improving access to the housing market. Banks should lend to buyers as well as builders so that people with a regular income can buy homes,” said one construction company businessman.According to Dr Maung Maung Lay, general secretary of the Union of Myanmar Federation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry, bank loans for borrowers with a regular income could benefit all parties.“Provided banks are careful only to lend to people with a regular income who can repay the loan, property values could increase,” he added. – Translated by Thiri Min Htun

Title: Traders seek other routes to bypass Myawaddy closure
News_content: Thailand-Myanmar bilateral trade this financial year is likely to be down about 40 percent because of persistent border closures, said Mr Prajuab Supinee, Thailand’s commercial counsellor in Yangon.          “Maybe trade will fall by 20 to 40pc compared with last year because the border closure has affected every kind of business,” he said.According to Mr Prajuab, about 80pc of total bilateral trade was via the border, and Myawaddy accounted for 60pc of that figure.A further 10pc is through Tachileik, 10pc is through Kawthaung and the remaining 20pc is seaborne.This means that the proportion of trade that passes through Myawaddy is about half of the trade between the two countries.Mr Prajuab said the Thai government had aimed to increase bilateral trade by about 5pc in the 2010-2011 fiscal year, but now expected that this target would not be met.During the first five months of the current financial year – from April to August – Thailand exported about US$300 million worth of goods to Myanmar and imported goods valued at about $1 billion – primarily natural gas – he said.“Trade decreased when the border closed on July 12,” he added.Myanmar closed the Mae Sot-Myawaddy border crossing at the bridge across the Moei River on that date, he said.Border trade is important for the two countries because it is cheaper than air or sea transportation.Thailand is Myanmar’s biggest trade partner, followed by Singapore, China, India, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Japan, South Korea and Indonesia, according to figures from the Ministry of Commerce.“Thai products are expensive in Myanmar because of transportation costs. Yangon is a big market for Thai products,” said Mr Prajuab.“The current situation is a problem for traders, who don’t know when the Mae Sot-Myawaddy border bridge will reopen,” he said.Myanmar’s Border Trade Department instructed local traders earlier this month to import Thai products via Tachileik in Shan State and Kawthoung in Tanintharyi Region to resolve the shortage of Thai goods and counteract price increases.“Bilateral trade through Tachileik accounts for only 10pc of total border trade ,” said Mr Prajuab.Amid fears that the Myawaddy checkpoint may not open until after the November 7 election, Mr Prajuab said: “That would be too long. Both sides want to trade.”He believed cross-border trade with China at Muse had increased as a result of the ongoing Myawaddy closure.Some Myanmar traders are trying to import and export goods via Myeik by sea, he said.“Trade via Myeik is limited. The main market is Yangon, then Mandalay,” said Mr Prajuab, adding that his government was keen to maintain its market in Yangon, the former capital.“I don’t know how long we can maintain it, because Chinese products are very popular but we don’t need to worry as far as quality is concerned,” said Mr Prajuab.“The import of Chinese products has increased by 10 to 15pc this year. Customers like Thai products, but sometimes they can’t get hold of them.”Speaking of the need to change the way Thai companies viewed Myanmar, Mr Prajuab said: “I want Thai people to come here and take a look at Myanmar before deciding to invest. That is why I arrange lots of business matching meetings,” he said. Increased investment would follow increased trade, he said.

Title: Myanmar to take part in CABIS mining forum
News_content: Myanmar will participate in the China-ASEAN Mining Cooperation Forum for the first time at the 7th annual China-ASEAN Business and Investment Summit (CABIS) next month, said the leader of the Myanmar delegation.          U Aye Lwin, executive committee member of the Union of Myanmar Federation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry (UMFCCI), is leading a group of 30 officials, and will use the forum to deliver a presentation on mining exports and the level of investment in the sector.U Aye Lwin said the goal of the presentation is to encourage further foreign investment in the mining industry.“We hope that foreign companies will invest in our mining sector. Their investment would provide high quality mining technology and equipment,” he said.U Aye Lwin added that Myanmar is eager to attract mining investment from any country, not just from ASEAN members.CABIS will be held in Nanning, China, from September 6 to 7, and the body has sponsored 15 exhibition booths at a cost of US$550 each for the Mining Cooperation Forum.U Aye Lwin said that the Myanmar Traders Association, which is under the UMFCCI, was contacted by CABIS about running a booth in mid-July.In addition to delivering a presentation, the Myanmar delegation has arranged for a tour of the Chinese mining industry.The UMFCCI believes Myanmar’s mining sector has significant development potential due to its rich deposits of gems, nickel, lead and copper. According to UMFCCI statistics, by the close of 2009 roughly 60 foreign countries had invested almost US$1.4 billion in Myanmar’s mining industry.

Title: China calling
News_content: A delegation from China visited Myanmar earlier this month to drum up support for the seventh annual China-ASEAN Expo (CAEXPO), to be held from October 20-24 in Nanning, in China’s southern Guangxi province. CAEXPO Vice Secretary General Nong Rong talked to The Myanmar Times about the opportunities on offer for Myanmar companies at the expo and the growing trade between the two countries.          This is the seventh CAEXPO. Has Myanmar been well represented in the past?Myanmar has been at all six expos and chartered an independent exhibition hall in the Pavilion of Commodity Trade at the last three. It has hosted 494 booths over that time and 1520 exhibitors and trade visitors from Myanmar have attended, signing trade deals worth US$43.648 million. With support from the governments of the two countries, CAEXPO will continue to provide opportunities for Myanmar enterprises to explore international markets.Are any changes planned for this year?As the first expo after the establishment of the China-ASEAN Free Trade Area (CAFTA), the event is of great significance and presents new highlights. To maintain its high profile, the 7th CAEXPO will be held concurrently with the China-ASEAN FTA Achievement Exhibition to promote China-ASEAN cooperation. We are also adding four new pavilions in line with relevant agreements under the China-ASEAN FTA, such as the Pavilion of Trade in Services, which focuses on financial services, logistics services and educational exchange services. There will also be specialised exhibition sections like a jewellery section and an ASEAN brands section. We will also hold a series of high-end forums on the theme of CAFTA and new opportunities to expand bilateral cooperation in various fields.CAFTA came into effect on January 1, with Myanmar committing to scrap tariffs on 90 pc of goods traded with China by 2015. What impact has the FTA had so far?Chinese statistics for the first four months of this year show bilateral trade with ASEAN countries grew 76.8pc compared to the same period last year to US$1.32 billion. Myanmar’s exports to China soared by 72.4pc while imports from China increased 79pc [no figures were given], showing the effect of the FTA has been equal for the two countries. The FTA has also increased two-way investment in the region and Myanmar is an important destination for Chinese investment.The signing of the China-ASEAN FTA Agreement on Trade in Services and Investment Agreement will open the services sector in both countries and provide a more stable and transparent investment environment. ASEAN is now the 5th largest export market and import source of services for China and Myanmar, being an important ASEAN member, boasts huge potential for cooperating with China on trade in goods and services and investment.How are preparations going for Myanmar exhibitors?Myanmar’s Ministry of Commerce, a CAEXPO co-sponsor, is organising enterprises to bring their cutting-edge products to the event. Myanmar will have 96 commodity booths, the same as last year, and an exhibition area to promote Mandalay, your City of Charm. Officials from your investment authority will also attend to attract more Chinese investment. The Union of Myanmar Federation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry, the Myanmar Forest Products & Timber Merchants Association, the Beans & Sesame Seeds Merchants Association, Myanmar Pulses, Myanmar Agro Based Food Processors & Exporters Association, the Myanmar Fisheries Federation and the Myanmar Industries Association have all agreed to bring their member enterprises and support us in promoting the event to develop trade.

Title: Garment factories hindered in new recruitment drive
News_content: Labour recruitment in the garment is rising sharply, an industry source said last week.          U Myint Soe, president of Myanmar Garment Manufacturers’ Association, said two factors were driving the employment upswing – an increase in orders from garment buyers abroad, particularly South Korea, and new factories started up by Chinese and Vietnamese companies. “These are creating demand for new workers,” said U Myint Soe.U Than Ye, operations manager for a South Korean-owned garment factory at the Dagon Industrial Zone, said international orders had bounced back and a number of new factories have been announced.“These two factors have increased the number of workers in my industrial zone,” U Than Ye said.U Zaw Min Oo, the managing director of Crocodile garment factory, said manufacturers supplying the South Korean and Japanese markets had recently boosted output and overtime. But he added that orders from Europe and Latin America were stagnant.He said Myanmar was poised to benefit from recent labour unrest in China, uncertainty over the depth of the Chinese labour pool, increasing raw material costs, rising wages and strengthening workplace laws.However, Myanmar faces its own problems, he added.“Despite the increase in orders we’ve received, we cannot enjoy the wages that other workers in developing countries get,” U Zaw Min Oo said.He added that part of the reason behind the labour shortage is the loss of skilled garment workers to better paying positions at Mae Sot in Thailand and Malaysia.“We are running at maximum capacity right now with the current workforce we have,” U Zaw Min Oo said.“It is crucial that we recruit workers now if we’re going to meet our new orders” he added.U Than Ye said his company was struggling to keep up with the increase of orders from South Korea since May.“Our workforce of 600 is only enough for normal demand and we don’t really have enough for the orders we’ve just received. We’re recruiting another 100 employees to fill this demand,” U Than Ye said.But he said finding the workers has proven difficult because new factories have sprung up.U Than Aung Kyaw, director of the Directorate of Trade, said that a number of foreign companies have requested information about setting up factories here. But, the exact numbers are hard to come by. An MGMA official confirmed that interest in Myanmar as a garment manufacturer is heating up.“A number of garment companies have recently submitted applications to Myanma Investment Commission to operate garment factories here under the foreign direct investment law,” he said.One of the new factories is owned by Opal company and will be opened in the South Dagon Industrial Zone. Opal already operates a large garment factory in Hlaing Tharyar Industrial Zone that employs 4000 workers and the company is looking to recruit 1000 new workers for the South Dagon factory, an official from the South Dagon Industrial Zone management committee said last week.U Zaw Myo, a line supervisor at a garment factory in Shwe Pyi Thar Industrial Zone, said: “If we cannot get enough workers, it’s going to be difficult to meet export deadlines.”He added that SGI, which was set up through German foreign direct investment, is also recruiting hundreds of workers, using higher-than-normal wages to lure employees.Another issue slowing down hiring has been a government directive aimed at preventing terrorist attacks or sabotage at industrial zones.After Thingyan industrial zone management committees were told to closely scrutinise new recruitments.“Our recruitment policy in the garment industry is that new workers are appointed through the recommendation of current employees, whether they are friends or family,” U Myint Soe said.The total workforce employed by the garment industry is estimated at more than 85,000 in the 120 factories in Yangon’s industrial zones. Factories owned or operated by South Korean firms are believed to employ about 40 percent, or 37,000, of these.Garment exports remained almost unchanged from the 2008-09 to 2009-10 fiscal year approximately about US$280 million, according to MGMA statistics.

Title: Malaysian business talks point to growth
News_content: Bilateral trade between Myanmar and Malaysia is on the way up.          And the Union of Myanmar Federation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry (UMFCCI) is doing its best to see it keeps going that way.Together with the Myanmar Industrial Association (MIA), the UMFCCI held a business matching session last week with the Association of Chinese Chambers of Commerce and Industry of Malaysia (ACCCIM) in Yangon to discuss how to further develop trade. The Malaysian party included about 30 members, all of whom had travelled to Myanmar to investigate opportunities on the local market. Most of the businessmen were seeking joint venture partnerships in manufacturing, trading and services in industrial products.A UMFCCI delegate said that in 2008-2009, trade between Myanmar and Malaysia leapt to a total of US$662.17 million, nearly three times higher than previous years, with exports from Myanmar of $311.69 million and imports of $350.48 million, according to the Central Statistical Organisation.“I think in 2008 Malaysian investors probably returned to Myanmar from other ASEAN countries,” said Dr Khin Aung Myint, a UMFCCI member.Malaysia invests in a total of 36 Myanmar enterprises, in oil and gas, manufacturing, real estate, hotels and livestock, participants at the meeting were told.Principal export items to Malaysia are products based on timber, agriculture and mining, and import items are steel, electrical goods, construction materials, chemicals and plastic products and machinery.“I’m here to look for human resources. I believe Myanmar has great potential in natural and human resources – Myanmar workers who come to Malaysia are not only good at their jobs, but also in languages,” said Mr Michael Heah, managing director of IRC Global Search, an international recruitment and outsourcing of manpower firm.He said that he was seeking skilled and unskilled manpower for manufacturing in electronics, garments, oil and gas, furniture and offer the human resources IT software for time attendance, process counter, training, education and HR and business consultancy.“We came to look at opportunities, we believe that Myanmar has great potential for investment, especially for ASEAN countries. I think this is also the right time because the financial crisis has nearly finished, and the economy of all the countries seem to be recovering,” said Mr Wong Choon Seng, the managing director of Saba Ready Mixed Concrete.“I was here 10 years ago and now I can see that there has been lots of activity and development, so we believe over the next three to five years, there should be a lot of economic opportunities available here,” he said.“Initially, we should look for what we can supply, and then we can get involved in the local Myanmar businesses, we have to look at what potential businesses here might be. The main attraction for us with Myanmar is that it has a loosely similar background and English is widely used. We believe that inflation is not too high either,” he said.“I’m just trying to look at all of the opportunities and try to understand the nature of business here. Then I will return and discuss these with our members,” said Loh Liam Hiang, the president of Johor Bahru Chinese Chambers of Commerce and Industry.

Title: Improved  electricity for Yangon industry
News_content: Htoo Trading and a Chinese partner will start work on a coal-fired power plant next July that will supply electricity to Yangon’s industrial zones, U Sein Oo, a director of the Htoo Group of Companies, told The Myanmar Times on March 17.          The US$300 million project will be implemented by the Ministry of Electric Power (1), Htoo Trading and Huaneng Lancang River Hydropower under the build, operate, transfer system, whereby the private companies will finance the construction and then operate the plant for a minimum of 20 years before transferring it back to the government.Htoo Trading will provide the majority of the investment, U Sein Oo said, while the Chinese company will supply the technology and most of the machinery. They will also be responsible for training local technicians to operate the plant.The plant, to be located on a 250-acre site in Htantabin township, Yangon Division, will initially provide 135 megawatts (MW) but that is expected to rise to 270MW after six months, he said.The project – Myanmar’s first coal-fired power plant – should be completed by the start of 2013.“The construction work will be complete within two and a half years. We will start providing electricity to industrial zones after two years as the first step,” said U Sein Oo.The plant will use coal from Kalewa mine in Sagaing Division and the electricity generated will supply factories in Yangon’s three industrial zones: Hlaing Tharyar, Shwe Pyi Thar and Shwe Lin Pan. Any surplus electricity generated will be diverted to meet domestic demand.To generate the maximum amount of power, the plant will require 3000 tonnes of coal a day, or more than 1 million tonnes a year.Myanmar produces about 250,000 tonnes of coal a year, according to government figures but there is potential for expansion.If Kalewa cannot provide enough, more will be imported from ASEAN countries, U Sein Oo said.“We will transport the coal along the Chindwin [River] and store at least six months’ supply near the plant,” said U Sein Oo. “The site of the plant has been selected bearing in mind the need to transport and unload coal.”He added that, as an environmental protection measure, the plant would be fitted with a smoke control system to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases.No price has yet been set for the power to be generated. The Ministry of Electric Power (2) charges domestic users K25 (about 2.5 US cents) per kilowatt hour and industry K50.Yangon’s electricity consumption is more than 300MW, but the actual demand is about double.U Myat Thin Aung, chairman of Hlaing Tharyar industrial zone, said there were about 1100 businesses in the three zones. While electricity consumption figures for Shwe Pyi Thar were not available, U Myat Thin Aung said total electricity consumption at Hlaing Tharyar and Shwe Lin Pan is 88MW but demand is actually much higher.U Sein Oo said he expected the three zones to consume at least 200MW when the plant comes online.

Title: Energy exports to drive 8.6pc GDP growth: ADB
News_content: Energy exports, mining and construction will fuel annual Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth of 8.6 percent to 2030, an Asian Development Bank (ADB) report says.          Electrification, or the percentage of households connected to the electricity grid, is projected to rise to 80pc over the same period, while primary energy demand will increase by 2.6pc annually, slightly above projections for the region and almost double the global average.Mr Edito Barcelona, a consultant with the ADB who worked on the report, Energy Outlook for Asia and the Pacific, said the GDP growth projection was based on government policies and other information reported by Myanmar government officials during ASEAN meetings and workshops.“In modelling, we assumed that this GDP growth could come from energy exports such as oil, natural gas and hydroelectricity which would also spur growth in other sectors of the economy,” Mr Barcelona said.Dr Sean Turnell, a professor of economics at Australia’s Macquarie University and editor of Burma Economic Watch, said natural gas sales would not provide any new impetus to GDP growth until new projects came online in 2013.“It’s true that Myanmar’s energy sector will be the source of rising export surpluses into the future – and hence a net positive contributions to GDP growth – but there’s no reason to see this sector being a growing contributor to this end in the coming year,” Dr Turnell.“I think there will be growth in Myanmar and the report is right to note the stimulus of the pipeline construction and various other energy investments – but these are not large and have small multipliers into the broader economy, as Chinese construction often involves imported Chinese workers, for instance,” Dr Turnell said.Natural gas exports are expected to almost double over the next decade as the Shwe and Zawtika projects come online and Mr Barcelona said these profits, augmented with foreign investment, could then be used to fund the electrification.“To reach 80pc [electrification] in 2030, Myanmar needs to invest in increasing its electricity generating facilities, extension of its transmission and distribution lines as well as substation capacities to currently un-electrified areas in the country,” he said.

Title: Chinese  VP Xi pays  2-day visit
News_content: Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping arrived in Myanmar on December 19 for a two-day visit as part of a four-nation Asian tour.          The visit “is bound to generate positive, far-reaching and major influence on the bilateral ties under new situation and it will push the bilateral ties towards a long and stable neighbourly, friendly and cooperative ones with new vigour”, the Chinese ambassador to Myanmar, Mr Ye Dabo, was quoted as saying by China’s state-run Xinhua newsagency .Mr Xi travelled to Myanmar from South Korea, where he arrived on December 16.Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Jiang Yu said on December 10 the vice president would visit Japan, South Korea, Myanmar and Cambodia during his nine-day tour.The tour will wind up on December 22.Close cooperation on diplomatic and economic affairs has seen Chinese and Myanmar government officials regularly visit their counterparts in Beijing and Nay Pyi Taw in recent years.In May, Vice Senior General Maung Aye visited China and invited Mr Xi to visit Myanmar at a convenient time.China is Myanmar’s fourth largest source of foreign investment, after Thailand, the United Kingdom and Singapore.To the end of September 2009, China has made US$1.33 billion of contracted foreign investment in Myanmar, with the mining sector comprising the largest share with $866 million, followed by hydropower ($280 million) and oil and gas ($124 million).Trade volume between Myanmar and China has also increased rapidly in recent years.In 2008, bilateral trade hit $2.6 billion, up from less than $1 billion five years earlier.

Title: Teaching to a different tune
News_content: Teaching at the Khayay International Preschool is anything but ordinary. Visit a class on three different days during any given week and you’ll see something unusual taking place: Classes are taught to children in four different languages.          It may sound like a marketing gimmick and the school’s founders and directors, Toru and Hitomi Iwasaki, freely admit children will not emerge from the preschool fluent in English, Myanmar, Japanese and Chinese.Luckily, that’s not the point. The aim is to best prepare children for learning languages in the future by exposing their growing minds – and ears – to as wide a range of sounds as possible.Humans hear sounds – or audible wave frequencies that are measured in Hertz (Hz) – ranging from about 100Hz to 15,000Hz, with every language having its own, unique band.At one of that scale is Russian, which has an extremely broad frequency – from 125Hz to 10,000Hz – while others, like Japanese, make do with a far narrower frequency band.The Iwasakis believe – and they are back by plenty of empirical and anecdotal evidence – that exposure to the broadest hertz band possible while children’s minds and ears are at their most receptive stage will leave children with a better foundation to learn languages later in life.“We understand that we are unable to fully teach all of those four languages to the children while they are here. We aim to familiarise them with those sounds so they will be more easily able to recognise them later,” says Mr Iwasaki.Anyone who has raised a child will be aware just how quickly they learn new things, languages included. Conversely, many people who have tried to learn a language later in life will know it can seem fiendishly tricky – particularly when trying to differentiate similar sounds.“Children’s brains are very flexible from the age of two onwards and are easily able to recognise more than just their mother language,” he says.“For many Myanmar children there will be very limited opportunities to learn those other three languages and the language they have picked up here will probably be lost unless they are pursued outside of their next school.“But we believe that if we teach them these sounds, at this early age, then they will remember them at a later stage.”It’s fitting that the school was conceived by Toru and Hitomi Iwasaki, since Japanese has a narrow hertz band and the teaching of foreign languages does not start in Japan until a child reaches 12 years of age – just as a normal child’s aural comprehension learning ability is tapering off, according to Thompson and Nelson’s The Developmental Course of Human Brain Development, a research paper published by the University of California, Los Angeles.Somewhat more anecdotal are Mrs Iwasaki’s early experiences trying to learn English, as well as those of the couple’s children.“I always wondered why some people are able to speak so many languages and if that was just some kind of talent they had,” Ms Iwasaki says.“When I was 11 I went on a school camp to Manila that was conducted exclusively in English and I struggled very hard initially. But within two weeks I could make out the words that people were using, even though nobody was actually teaching me,” she said.Mr Iwasaki’s position at the United Nations meant all three of their daughters were brought up in countries with different languages, which seems to have broadened their aural capacity.All three are able to speak at least three languages and were brought up in the United States, Africa or Myanmar, depending on where Mr Iwasaki’s UN posting took the family.While the school instructs in Japanese, English, Myanmar and Chinese, it still manages to maintain a preschool atmosphere. The subjects are exactly what you’d expect and include arts and crafts, singing, physical education and some gentle science.Discard or ignore the multiple language instruction and you’re left with a top-notch kindergarten in an attractive complex just off Parami Road, not far from the seven mile junction. The classrooms are inviting and comfortable, while the grounds are quiet and safe.Assigning colours to the preschool’s classrooms, which include soft blues, pinks, greens and oranges, was a labour of love for Mrs Iwasaki and builds on a lifelong fascination with colour. Each colour was chosen to create an emotional link for the children – blue for the youngest children and pink for the oldest class to show confidence and prepare them for the next stage in their education.All of the rooms are designed for comfort and practicality but with a number of subtle points to encourage learning, even while the children are effectively at play.A case in point is the library, which includes a growing collection of children’s books published in the four languages.The centre of the room is taken up by a small tunnel maze and, while unable to properly demonstrate the workings of the maze due to its diminutive proportions, Mr Iwasaki says it teaches children about “resilience competency”.“They crawl into the maze by themselves and it’s quite confined and dark inside,” he says, pointing to the escape holes cut in the top for children who become overwhelmed by the experience. “And they must navigate their way through to the other end by making the right decisions. But they must always consider on the maze itself because the spaces are small and it’s possible to hit your head if you’re not concentrating on your movement,” he says.The preschool also contains a science room, an art room and a music room. Ms Iwasaki says she was surprised how quickly the children learn new songs, irrespective of the language. Three repetitions is often enough for the children to remember the words and sing along, she says.“They remember with the songs that go with the music so quickly,” she adds.Other subtle learning aids are wall-mounted boxes with objects inside that are placed outside classrooms to assist children identify the particular room.As might be expected, finding teachers ready to teach in such a unique environment is no easy task, so the Iwasakis have set up a training centre to produce them. Sixteen teachers have so far completed the three-year training program since the centre was established in 2004.Of those 16 graduate teachers, seven are employed at the school to manage the 12 students currently enrolled at Khayay. But how are those teachers able to teach in so many languages?“Obviously it would be best if we were able to find teachers who spoke the four languages themselves but this is obviously fairly difficult,” Ms Iwasaki says.Instead, the teachers rely on “team teaching”. Each teacher specialises in a language other than Myanmar and then devises daily lesson plans in that language.The other teachers learn the basic words and numbers of the other languages but bring in the specialist teacher for specific lessons. There are also audio CDs to assist teachers and, accordingly, all classrooms have in-built sound systems.To avoid confusion for both children and teachers, only one language is used during a given day, although misunderstandings are generally clarified in a child’s strongest language, which is usually Myanmar.Tuition fees are handled by negotiation but are certainly significantly lower than other international-standard preschool centres in Yangon.“We’d like to make our fees cheaper than [what they are] but there is an investment here that we must continue to pay for and the training we provide [to teachers] at our centre is free,” Toru says.As for why the Iwasakis picked Myanmar – clearly a question that has been put to them before – Ms Iwasaki says, “It’s because we were already here.”

Title: Geo consultant urges miners to start small
News_content: Small-scale mining may present more opportunities than large-scale excavations, a geologist said last week.          Smaller mines can be opened with less investment, then expanded when they start to show results, said U Aung Kyin, a geological consultant working for AK-Associate Company, which advises excavating companies in the local mining sector.The owner of a small mine can invite partners or shareholders to finance expansion if significant mineral deposits are found, U Aung Kyin told The Myanmar Times, adding that Myanmar mining law allowed small-scale mines to sell directly to buyers without having to build a huge plant to refine the metal.U Aung Kyin said some foreign countries had been investing in Myanmar’s mining sector since 1992. China had increased its investment by 70 percent since then, he said.“At present, Chinese businessmen have been investing in a lot of small-scale mines, both directly and indirectly,” said U Aung Kyin.However, Chinese investors tend to do business with their compatriots on the basis of oral agreements alone, without a written contract, he added.U Aung Kyin said that if a businessman from Yunan province invested in a small mine in Myanmar, he would contact another Chinese from Muse who would, in turn, deal with another Chinese, perhaps from Mandalay. As a result, he said, a host of different actors become involved.The Ministry of Mines gives two-year permits for mining excavation and defines the areas to be worked in terms of the metal being excavated, said an official from the ministry. He said that the permit could be extended for a further two years following a government survey.More than 60 companies are excavating lead and zinc in southern and northern Shan State, he said, and about 30 companies were mining tin and tungsten in Tanintharyi Division.

Title: Garment demand from SK strong
News_content: Korean firms are ordering more garments from Myanmar as tension along the border between North and South Korea has reportedly raised concerns about the security of the industrial zones there.          Though exports of hardwoods, fisheries and other products from Myanmar to Korea have fallen, garment orders from Korea are up significantly, say industry observers.“Orders from South Korea have increased by about 30pc compared with this time last year,” said U Zaw Min Oo, managing director of the Crocodile garment factory.Mainly because of the situation along the border between South and North Korea, sub-contracts for garment orders now come to Myanmar instead of to the border industrial zone, U Zaw Min Oo said.Korean embassy first secretary Mr Park Kil Chae told The Myanmar Times that relations between the two Koreas had become complicated, and the garment industry in Gaesung Industrial Zone in North Korea hesitated to expand its investment.“Under these circumstances, Korean buyers are expected to increase orders to Myanmar. But I am not sure when they will get into their stride in this country,” Mr Park said.U Zaw Min Win, who is also a secretary of Myanmar Garment Manufacturers’ Association (MGMA), said that factories producing work destined for the Korean market had to raise productivity and increase overtime.At the same time, orders from the European Union and Latin America continued to decline, though Japanese orders remained constant.U Myint Soe, president of MGMA estimated the total workforce employed in Myanmar’s garment industry at more than 85,000, in 120 factories in Yangon’s industrial zones.Of these, about 37,000 workers, or about 40pc of the total, were employed in garment factories operated by Korean investors.Garment exports to South Korea stood at US$30.4 million in 2008, slightly up from $30.2 million the previous year.“I think garment export orders to Korea are increasing because consumers tend to reduce their expenditure in the gloomy times and to buy cheaper,” said U Myint Soe.He said this was a very good opportunity for the Myanmar garment industry because it allowed Korean consumers to see the good quality and reasonable price of Myanmar products.Though the export volume of garments from Myanmar to South Korea increased by 16.2pc in the first half of this year, to $14.4 million, compared to the same period last year, South Korea is one of many countries affected by the worldwide recession, which has reduced consumer spending. However, World Bank senior vice president Justin Lin has predicted that economic recovery could come to Korea earlier than in many OECD countries.The recession may also have helped improve Myanmar’s trading position with China, Mr Park believes. As the average monthly wage of Chinese factory workers has risen to about $300-400 nowadays, orders for labour-intensive products such as garments are now going outside the country, he said.The same is true in Vietnam, where the average wage has risen to about $100. Myanmar workers earn from $40 to $70 depending on overtime.“Myanmar workers are mostly reliant on the overtime,” said Ko Zaw Than, a supervisor in one of the Korean garment factories in Hlaing Tha Yar Industrial Zone, adding that the factory could pay more overtime because of the increase in Korean orders. The average worker now earned about K50,000 ($50) a month, Ko Zaw Than said.
